div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marsailles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnightof 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcoutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt - - - - - - - -SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly 6 p.m., Wednesday for Port Sudan and Saukin direct returning from Suakin evry Wednesday at noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodbidah, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Reserve Fund... £500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.

div.head: THE STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: Since the days of the great Mohamed Aly the name of Cairo has been linked with the history of the progress of electrical science by the fact that not only was the electric light installation which he had erected in his gardens at Shoubra the first to be erected in Africa, but it even placed Cairo ahead of London and Paris themselves in this respect. Now, after the lapse of many years, Cairo has again secured for itself a place in the history of electrical science, having established it record as the first town or station in the African continent to adopt electricity as an aid in the signalling of its railways. This was done on Saturday last, when Mr. James- Punter, the chief of the Signalling Department of the State Railways Administration, presided with his accustomed vim and tireless energy at the inauguration of the first section of the new electric-pneumatic signalling installation that has just been completed under his supervision.

As our readers are aware, the Railway Commission which lately issued its report upon the administration of the State Railways, in a somewhat doubtful and hesitating way, expressed the opinion that this new installation was an unnecessary luxury, but we are satisfied that if the Commission could have had a really sufficient opportunity of studying the question they would, so far from even hinting at disapproval, have warmly commended the wise foresight the Administration have displayed in the adoption of this system of signalling for the Cairo station. How wise that foresight has been only time can fully show, but the truth is that if only needs a fair knowledge of the merits of the system, and of the circumstances which specially call for its application, to see that Cairo is a station which urgently required the adoption of this or some nearly equivalent system. It is of course quite outside of our scope to go into anything like technical details here, but we may say that, taking only one of the great advantages that the system offers, our readers can judge for themselves of its utility. The advantage to which we refer is the economy of space. Cairo station is, owing to the peculiar circumstances under which it has developed from its first primitive and very limited form, from the railway man's point of view, a most awkward station. The main through line connecting the Lower and Upper Egypt lines winds from the terminus platform to the riverside in a serpentine fashion that opposes great difficulty to effective signalling; and to make the matter worse, to provide for its constantly growing need of room for locomotive sheds, carriage depots, goods platforms, sidings, repairing shops, and other necessary and absolutely indispensable conveniences of the service, it has had to branch off from this main line a number of sidings and line leading to these various sheds and depots, etc., both above and below the terminus platforms, every available inch of space being utilised in some form or other. The station has thus become a long, straggling, winding line with a number of branches springing from it and leading to large areas of auxiliary lines, and thus in addition to the eighty or so passenger trains arriving or starting from the terminus, there is the day and most of the night a restless bustling to and fro of engines and carriages and goods wagons passing from one part of the station to another in accordance with the exigencies of the service, and all this traffic has to be conducted under grave difficulties as to the signalling due to the irregular curving of the lines and the resulting impossibility of engine-drivers seeing signals until quite close to them. This fact alone shows how necessary it is in this station to adopt the most efficient method of signalling attainable. But to this complexity a most important feature of the ease to be added, is the scanty room that the main lines and auxiliary branches have. This is so small indeed as to be almost prohibitive of any attempt to provide effective signalling by the use of the ordinary mechanical apparatus, for this demands a very large amount of space, the necessary connecting rods, eta, for the working of the points and signals at some spots needing almost as much ground space as the lines themselves. Here the advantage of the electric-pneumatic system speaks for itself, for by this system, instead of a series of iron rods occupying at least as many feet of space in width as there are rods, the electric system employs only an air pipe and an electric cable carrying the necessary wires, all of which can be laid in an accessible and secure form in the space of a little more than what a couple of iron connecting rods would require. This fact alone quite justifies the adoption of this system for Cairo station.

There are several other advantages that this system of signalling offers, but space forbids our dealing with these at present, and the same imperative reason prevents our attempting to give our readers any idea of the nature, construction, or working of the apparatus it employs. This however we hope to be able to do in connection with the completion of the installation, which is now not very far off, and we must therefore now content ourselves with congratulating the Administration upon the success that has amended its enterprise and upon the efficiency of its Signalling Depart merit, which, under the direction of its chief, who is a specially trained expert in railway signalling, is very evidently accomplishing very valuable work. It is, we believe, an accepted axiom of railway work in the present day that the efficiency of the services rendered by any given line must to a very large extent be dependent upon the efficiency of its signalling this efficiency being, when all has been said and done, the one really possible means of increasing the working power of a line, since it is obviously useless for a railway administration to provide extra power or vehicles to meet increasing traffic, if, owing to defective or insufficient signalling, the free movement of these is impeded as it must be when the signalling is riot up to the highest modern standard in all respects.

div.head: Alexandria Maternity Home.
div.p: We have received a donation of £1 from Mrs. Arthur Payton in aid of the above institution.

div.head: Military Parade.
div.p: The Cairo garrison and the cadets of the Military College will parade at 9 a.m. on Wednesday at Abbassieh.
Rifle Meeting.
The annual Rifle Meeting will be held on the ranges at Abbassieh on the 12th, 13th, 14th, and 15th February next.
Army Lectures.
A lecture will be given on Thursday next by Lient. Cnl Markham, 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, the subject being "'A Few Remarks on the Japanese Army."
Quadrille Party,
The quadrille party which was to have been given in the sergeants' mess at Mnstapha Pasha yesterday evening has been postponed to tomorrow (Wednesday).
National Hotel.

The Bracale orchestra will play for dinner at the National Hotel, Cairo, on Wednesday evening. The grill-room at this hotel has now been opened, and patrons may have hot or cold suppers served after the theatre.
Fires.

Two fires took place in Alexandria yesterday, one in a shop belonging to an Italian in Souk el-Maz, and the other in a hotel in Post Office-street. A British subject, employed in the Sudan Government Railways, who was staying at the hotel, was seriously burnt.
P. W. D. Contracts.

The masonry works a Kosheisha and Bahambehin and on the Moleik drain hive been adjudged to the following contractors: Section 1, L. Santrapeza; 2, Ant. Eddé, 3, Mich. Mershac; 4, P. A. Filo ; 5, M. Eisnom; 6, Michaelides and Sella; 7, L Santrapeza ; 8. Eug, Bichara; 9, V Sogori.
Review by Khedive.

Residents and visitors who are desirous of witnessing the review of troops to be held at Abbassieh by the Khedive, on the 8th inst., on the anniversary of his Highness's accession, can obtain tickets on application to the Assist ant Adjutant General, War Office, Egyptian Army. It is requested that such applications be marked on the cover "Residents carriage enclosure," or "Visitors carriage enclosure," according to the requirements of the applicant. These tickets will not be ready for issue before the 6th inst.
Cairo Library.

Several charges have lately been made in the working of this library, which it is hoped will add to its usefulness. It is now open in the morning as well as in the afternoon; every week day from 10.30 to 12, and from 4.30 to 6 in the evening Subscriptions for the magazine are also received there and all particulars given concerning the library. A box for letters has been placed on the door, and all letters should be henceforth addressed to The Librarian, Cairo Circulating Library, Sharia Boulak.
Seamen's Home 'Xmas Treat.

The following is a list of contributors and helpers furnished by Rev. Hugh P. Reid:— Mr. C. H. Anderson, Mrs. J. Davies Bryan, Miss Hewat, Major Pringle, Mrs. Peck, Miss Wood, Misses Webb, and Miss West. Contributions are also gratefully acknowledged from Mesdames Zogheb; M. Zogheb, Ant Benacbi, M. Sinadino, Miss Conatantidi, Miss Dora Davies, Miss Zatto Sinano, the National Bank of Egypt, Master Anast. Theodorski, M. Pericles Auastasiadi, Mr. Th. Rodocanachi, Mr. Antoni Ralli, Mr. John Balli, "P. H. C.," Miss Etha Papageorge, and Miss Demitri Joannidis.
In the list of acknowledgments by Lady Blomfield Mrs. Foster's contribution of roast beef was inadvertently omitted.
Maternity Home.

The 'Xmas Tree fête organised in aid of that deserving charity, the Alexandria Maternity Home, which took place at the Khedivial Hotel on Saturday last, was a most brilliant and successful function. It was attended by a bewildering number of fair members of Alexandria Society and an army of little ones, whose happy faces and charming costumes formed a very pleasing and harmonious coup d' ceil. The 'Xmas Tree was, of course, the centre of attraction, and it provided abundance of delight to the little folks. Dancing, too, was engaged in, to the strains of the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers (kindly lent for the occasion), which also discoursed a few well-chosen selections of music. A native conjuror gave a display of his ability without fee or charge, and a buffet was placed at the disposal of the children, who did ample justice to its contents. Altogether, the gathering was of a most enjoyable character, and will long be remembered by the little ones who were fortunate enough to be present.

div.head: THE GRAND CADISHIP
div.p: ANOTHER DEVELOPMENT.
SHEIKH YEHIA RETURNING

We learn that Sheikh Yehia, who was recently replaced as Grand Cadi of Egypt by Sheikh Djellal ed Din El Rumei, and whose dismissal by the Ottoman authorities evoked a respectful protest on the part of the Egyptian Government, has been restored to his office, and is returning to Cairo from Constantinople.
The reasons for this volte face are obscure, but its result is highly satisfactory to the Egyptian Government.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: A notice has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior informing pilgrims who intend to accompany the Mahmal that they must be at Suez awaiting the arrival of the Mahmal and escort on January 13.
No pilgrims whatever will be allowed to accompany the Mahmal train.
The number of Egyptian pilgrims who have arrived at Suez during the last week amounts to about seven thousand.
The total number of the Egyptian pilgrimage will, it is believed, consist of not more than eleven thousand pilgrims this year.

div.head: EGYPT AND BULGARIA.
div.p: Constantinople, Deo. 26

M. Dimitroff, formerly Bulgarian Agent in Constantinople, left this city for the Piraeus on Saturday. M. Dimitroff is on his way to Egypt in connection with the conclusion of a commercial arrangement between Egypt and Bulgaria.

div.head: SUDAN NOTES
div.p: El-Obeid, Dec. 17.

We are experiencing quite cold nights now here and rather high winds. Polo is in full swing three days a week. A new ground is to be laid out shortly so as to give the old one a rest, as it is getting somewhat soft and cut up.
The Director of Music E. A. arrived here yesterday, and is hard at work with our bands up here.
The new O. C. Camel Corps is on his way up here from Dueim. viz., Kaimakam Percival Bey. We shall be very shortly about twelve in mess.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: Suakin, Dec. 27.

The weekly mails from Suakin to Berber, which for many years have been carried by camel, will be discontinued from 1st January, 1906. The mails will henceforth leave here by passenger train twice a week for Berber, etc.
Mr. Devey, British Consul for Jeddah and the Red Sea Ports, arrived here last week on a short visit and left again for Jeddah.

The British steamer Bardistan arrived here on the 21st inst. from England with a consignment of rails for the Sudan Railways and left again yesterday to discharge the remainder of her cargo at Kurrachee. The Bardistan is the last steamer to put in at Suakin for the railway. Other steamers with material, etc, for the Sudan Government will in future discharge at Port Sudan, as all the pontoons and the floating crane will soon be removed from Suakin to that port.

Several English engine drivers and other workmen are leaving today by the Khedivial Mail S. S. Dakahlia for Suez, on the ruduction of the establishment by the Suakin Railway, as the line is now completed and their contracts have expired.
Mr. C. Archer, driver of the Suakin railway condensers, has resigned his appointment and leaves today for Alexandria by the Dakahlia.
Bimbashi Spencer, late Inspec or Suakin Moudirieb, has pasted through here en route to Khartonm to take up his new appointment as Assistant Civil Secretary to the Sudan Government.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: ALLEGED FRONTIER DISPUTE.
AUTHORITATIVE DENIAL OF RUMOUR

We are officially authorised to contradiot the rumour emanating from Constantinople as to an alleged frontier dispute between the Egyptian and Turkish Governments. The Egyptian Government is not constructing a military post at the further end of the bay of Bomba, 250 kilometres to the west of Sollum.

The report is believed to be inspired either by Anglophobes who wish to alarm Turkey and perhaps Italy by tales of British designs on Bomba, or by those Egyptophobes, unhappily too numerous in Turkish official circles, who are prone to show their annoyance at the progress Egypt has made with British help in the last 20 years, by attributing the most amazing designs to Egyptians of importance and by arresting or insulting Egyptian visitors to Syria and the Turkish ports.

div.head: THE WADY RAYAN.
div.p: Washington, Dec. 7.

The Senate passed a resolution, today, introduced by Senator Lodge, requesting from the President, if not incompatible with the public interests, the papers relating to a claim of Cope Whitehonse to certain desert lands in Egypt. It is represented that the lands claimed are now valued at $25,000,000.

div.head: RUSSIAN BATTLESHIP AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Monday.
The Russian battleship Cesarevitz arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon and entered the Canal at 6.30 this morning bound to Toulon for thorough repairs.

It will be remembered that this ship was one of the late Admiral Makaroff's battleships which attempted to run the blockade at Port Arthur, and subsequently took refuge at Kiouchaw owing to the serious damages she sustained at the hands of Togo's fleet.
The Cesarevitz, being only temporarily repaired, showed signs of the engagement.

div.head: NEW BUILDING AT PORT SAID.
div.p: Port-Said, Sunday.
We are informed that the new premises of the local branch of the Bank of Egypt Ltd., which have been under construction for some time will be occupied from the commencement of the New Year.
The building is on a fine scale and very ornamental. We understand, however, that most of the interior fittings, electric lighting, etc, will take a further five to six weeks to complete
When finished it will be considered one of the finest public buildings in Port Said.

div.head: "ANTAR" AT THE KHEDIVIAL.
div.p: Such was the chill and draught, so widespread the coughing and sneezing, that even the Bedouin dresses, the shepherds, the adjurations to the sun and desert, etc., could not hide the presence of winter—nor could we catch more than about two fifths of the play. It is the well-known Antar story, sentimentalized, for the real Antar was a great fighter, had a reasonably long married life, and died in battle. As a play the piece hangs fire from time to time, and does not quite "fit" here and there, in its various stages. So far as we could hear them, there were some good lines and fine phrases, chiefly in the longer passages; in dialogue the author occasionally tripped, and even tumbled down now and again. M. Daragon's figure and voice were highly suitable. Mme Moreno was less successful, rather strident at times, and if we may venture so far, not nearly so attractive as usual, not befog a brunette by nature. M. Monteux's measured, almost drawling, tones were effective, much more so than the sustained war cries of the others. These three are undoubtedly a class above the rest in their knowledge of the voice and its resources—not necessarily its force. We hope to see Mr. Chekri Ganem's play again once, or twice, if possible under quieter conditions, so as to form a more adequate opinion. After all an oriental production should obtain more attention than the average 1850 drama which so often holds the Cairo stage.

div.head: EXPORTS OF CIGARETTES.
div.p: The total quantity of cigarettes exported from Egypt last month was 60,475 kilos, as compared with 54,035 kilos in November of last year, an increase of 6,440 kilos. The exports for the eleven months of the year totalled 630,046 kilos, which is an increase of 70,816 kilos on the figures for the same period of 1904. Coming to importing countries, the largest increase was under the head of Germany, which increased her imports by 47,388 kilos. The next largest increase was in the case of France (10,829 kilos). Other increases are shown under the heads of British possessions in the Far East, Austria, Hungary, China, Holland, Italy, Sweden and Norway, etc. England imported 7,118 kilos less than last year, and other countries which showed decreases were Belgium, Spain, Portugal, Switzerland, America, and British Mediterranean possessions.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT.
div.p: POLICY OF THE DIRECTORS.
THE UNEXPENDED CAPITAL.

The ordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, was held on the 21st inst. at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, E C., Sir Auckland Colvin, K C.S.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E. (chairman of the company), presiding.
The secretary (Mr. F. J. Horne) having read the notice calling the meeting.

The Chairman said: The accounts show that we have not yet effected any sales of land and that we still have a large proportion of our capital uninvested, but this most not be held to mean that we could not either have sold our present holdings at a profit or increased them to the full extent of our resources if we had felt it to our interest to do so. We are not a merely speculative company, baying and selling as opportunity may offer, or looking to snatch immediate profits as the means of our prosperity. We regard the company as having for its object the placing of sound investments in land or similar property, which may require time to yield a good return, but which, with due care and development, are reasonably sore to give us adequate profits. Taking first the properties we have acquired, their development has depended and does depend in many cases upon the arrangements to be made by the Egyptian State Railway or the Delta Light Railways, but these are now for the most part sufficiently known to enable this work to be taken in hand, and arrangements are being made accordingly. It is stated in the report that some 479 feddans or acres of land have been purchased. It is necessary to explain that some 45 feddans are favorably situated in Cairo, Tantah and other towns, while the rest may be regarded as suburban. In addition to these purchases we have aquired a l-6th interest in a land purchase effected by another company, which is contiguous to a large area which again we hope to purchase in partnership when certain existing difficulties are removed. The earliest lots which we are about to take in hand are those in Cairo and its immediate vicinity, and here the company will shortly proceed to offer plots for Bale for building purposes and to build on its own account. It is proposed to offer a few of the said plots for sale by auction, in the first instance at a low upset price, but if certain properties we have purchased in the neighbourhood of the Helouan Railway prove as attractive as we have reason to hope, we may expect substantial profits from their development This may probably involve our building some villa residences, or aiding purchasers to erect their own buildings thereon. In Cairo and other important towns it will also probably prove most advantageous to build shops and offices and flats on land which we have purchased. These will certainly procure good rentals. A considerable portion of our unexpended capital is thus likely to be brought into use, but the main reason of this being so much larger at present than was anticipated is chiefly because greater delay than we could have expected has occurred in the definite making over to the Delta Light Railways of the Menoufieh Provinces. As you are probably aware, the price of land in our sphere of operations has increased so rapidly since this company started that whatever might prove to be its ultimate value it was clear to us that no immediate profit could be reckoned upon by purchases effected during a period of inflation, and the directors have hesitated to look up funds for an indefinite period with the possibility of a considerable reaction in the property market. You will have observed from the profit and loss account that the working charges of the company have been kept very low, but we consider that the time has now arrived when the Land Company should somewhat enlarge its staff, and some farther appointments will have to be made to cope with the work now to be entered upon. I may add that under arrangements made by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways your financial year will terminate in future at March 31st, so the next accounts will be for a half-year only, and will be presented to you six months hence, when I hope there will be increased signs of progress. I now move:

"That the report of the directors dated December 1st, 1905, together with statement of accounts and balance-sheet for the year ended September 30th, 1905, be and they are hereby approved, confirmed and adopted."
Major W. I le Breton seconded the resolution, and it was carried unanimously.
Mr. Wilkins moved, 'That the auditors to the company, Messrs. Frank Davies, Meredith and Co., be re-elected for the ensuing year at a remuneration of fifteen guineas."
Mr. Born seconded the resolution, and it was carried unanimously.
The meeting then terminated.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti arrived here on Sunday from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The S. S. Fabian (Westcott and Laurence Line) left Malta on the 30th ult. and is due here on Wednesday next, with general cargo from London.
The S. S. Scottish Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Sunday last, and is due at Alexandria, via Tunis and Malta, on or about January 16.

div.head: CONCERT AT BULKELEY.
div.p: THE DAISY CHAIN.
NOTABLE DISPLAY OF TALENT.

The concert given in the Parish Room, Bulkeley, in aid of the Church Expenses Fond of All Saints', Ramleh, on Friday last, was an ample guarantee of the existence of real amateur talent in the neighbourhood. The performance was opened with Mendelssohn's No. I Trio, for violin, piano, and violincello, played by Messrs. Artelli, Ehrlich and Ruffer respectively. The well-known andante movement of this trio was rendered with much taste and feeling and was immensely appreciated by the large audience assembled. The next item were two little songs sang by Mrs. Edward Moss, whose exceptionally cultivated style and beautiful tones were heard to foil advantage Her sympathetic and graceful rendering of the second song "My Treasure," was received with all the appreciation it deserved. Mr. H. V. Hall next appeared with two violin solos, one of which, the well-known "Simple Aveu," received a due acknowledgment of its graceful harmonies and contrasts. We were next favoured with a very old but none the less welcome friend in Mendelssohn's "Greeting," sang with much taste by Mrs. Violet Alderson and Miss Harden, and this was followed by a song from Mr. K. Macaulay, who gave a really delightful rendering of "I'll sing thee songs of Araby.'' Mr. E. Ehrlich was announced to sing, but unfortunately was prevented from doing so by a bad cold. Mrs. Edward Moss was again heard in a song entitled "Sunbeams," which was sung with snob spirit and feeling that the audience were clamorous in their demands for an encore, which was duly accorded. The final movement of Trio No. I was next played and seemed to give even greater satisfaction than its predecessor. It was played with a vigour and precision that quite stirred up the audience and at its termination it was received with a storm of applause. The next item, a song by Mr. Macaulay, "Hybrias the Cretan," though sang with great vigour, did not bring out the exceptional quality of his middle tones as his former song did. The programme was concluded by Mr. H. V. Hall, who played Raff's "Cavatina.'' In this he gave genuine pleasure, and it was evident that where his bowing lacked precision it was far more due to that nervousness which so often plays havoc with amateur violinists, than from any lack of musical and technical ability. It only remains to say that a concert which dis played such exceptional amateur talent has, by the verdict of all who enjoyed it, seldom been given.

A charming composition by Liza Lehmann, entitled "The Daisy Chain" (Twelve Songs of Childhood), formed the second part of the concert. The words of the songs were written by Lawrence Alda Tadema, R. L. Stevenson, Norman Gale W. B. Rands, and "Anon." The soprano parts were taken by Miss Carver, the oontralto by Mrs. W. R. Williams, the tenor by Mr. J. Parris, and the baritone by the Rev. R. F. Rynd. Mr. S. R. P. Carver accompanied with excellent taste upon the piano. The very successful rendering of this composition was marked by precision, a perfect balance of light and shade. An appreciative audience was, if anything, almost too eager to express its pleasure, and warmly applauded whenever an opportunity was given. Mr. Rynd organised this most successful concert, and was responsible for all the arrangements. We hope that it is but the first of similar musical treats of pleasure to which we may look forward. The Parish Room at Ramleh looked exceedingly well decorated with plants, eta, and serves admirably for each entertainments. We understand that the total receipts for the concert, which was for Ramleh Church Expenses Fund, amounted to P.T. 2,133.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We are glad to be able to state that Lord Cromer has completely recovered from his recent indisposition.
Bishop Blyth, Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem and the East, proposes to visit Egypt and the Sudan early this year.
The Venerable Beresford Potter, Anglican Archdeacon in Cyprus, is paying a visit to Egypt shortly.

The Rt. Rev. Henry C. Potter, Bishop of New York, who is now up the Nile, will make a stay of some duration in Egypt. The bishop says he will go to Rome in March to help Dr. R .J. Nevin, rector of the American Church, in the administration of confirmation.
Mr. C. Belinfante-Ostberg, Consul-General for Sweden, is staying at Shepheard's Hotel.
The Count and Countess of Hochberg, who arrived by the North German Lloyd steamer Hohenzollern, are staying at the Hotel s'Angleterre.

Among the latest arrivals at Shepheard's we notice: Baron von Gleichenstein and family, Baron and Baroness von Seldeneck, who are back from their trip to Fayoum; H.H. Prince Djemil Toussoun and suite, H.H. Price Mohamed Ibrahim and suite, Princess Cantacuzane, etc.

Last night's small dance at Shepheard's was a brilliant success. Besides the 360 tourists who are now staying at the famous hostelry, there was a large number of residents and visitors from other hotels who attended the dinner and the dance. Amongst many others the following wer noticed at dinner in the restaurant: - Prince Djemil Toussoum, Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, Baron and Baroness von Born, Mr. F.A. Kennedy and party. Mr. and Mrs. Odell and party, the Hon. Mrs. Sandilands with her son. Huntington Blanchard and a party of 7, Baron de Metaxa and a party of 10, Mr. and Mrs. Blake Baker and a party of 4, Mr. Mainger Stewart and some friends, Baron and Baroness von Gleichenstein and party of 4, General von Blucher and his daughter, Count Zamoyska, Messrs. Tueni and party, Mr. Belifante Ostberg and party, Dr. Kuyper, etc.

div.head:
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
REPORTED COLLAPSE.
TWENTY THUOSAND KILLED.
A REIGN OF TERROR.

div.p: Order is completely re-established. Trade and traffic are proceeding normally.
(Router)

The revolution seems to have collapsed with extraordinary suddenness. As yet it is impossible to determine the extent of the damage done, and the numbers of killed and wounded, bat it is expected that the first estimates of the slaughter caused by artillery fire will prove to have been exaggerated. It is felt that the Government has gained an important moral victory.
(Router)
The telegrams confirm that quiet is being restored in Moscow, Odessa, and St. Petersburg.
(Havas)

The Government is confident that the back of the revolution is broken with the collapse at Moscow, where the insurgents, after endeavouring to treat, were driven into a quarter, surrounded by troops, and exposed to artillery fire by which numbers were killed, while the remainder tied.
The collapse at Moscow had an immediate effect here, where work will be resumed tomorrow.
(Router)

The Council of Workmen has decided to suspend strikes and organise a general insurrection, meanwhile initiating a reign of terror. The Government has responded by a declaration that it will repress all preparations for a revolt with the utmost rigour.
(Router)
The damage done by Saturday's bombardment amounts to several millions of roubles. The inhabitants of the quarter bombarded, forewarned by the authorities, left prior to the bombardment.
(Router)
The troops massacred the revolutionaries. 20,000 people have been killed.
(Havas)
Order has been restored. Work is being resumed.
Disorders are reported from Conrland. (H.)

A proclamation of the Council of Ministers declares that the first duty of the Government consists actually in the restoration of order and in the application of the principles of the manifesto of the 30th October. Consequently, the officials who oppose the intentions of the Government and preach disobedience will be replaced.
(Havas)
An Anarchist threw four bombs in a restaurant here, of which three exploded, wounding five persons, the fourth exploded in a police station, killing two policemen and wounding five.
(Router)

Recognising that the subjugation of the Baltic provinces is a most formidable task, the Government is preparing for a winter campaign on a large scale. Troops are already entering Courland from four sides.
Wholesale arrests continue and the prisons are overflowing. Six hundred were arrested at Moscow after the fighting on Saturday, only a few of the leaders escaping.

The newspapers contain a terrible picture of the Siberian Railway to Cheliabinsk. The authorities have disappeared, and soldiers and sailors have pillaged all the stations. Irkutsk is in a state of complete anarchy.

The "Daily Telegraph" learns from Toki that the three Northern Provinces of Japan are confronted with the worst famine that bus occurred for 60 years. 680,000 persons are already in the last extremity.
(Router)
The Assize Court has sent to prison 26 signatories of the anti-militarist posters among them Herve, to four years, and Gohier to one year.
(Havas)

Twenty-six of the anti-military party have been convicted. Professor Herve, the apostle of the movement, was sentenced to four years' imprisonment, M. Urbain Gohier, a prominent Dreyfusard, to one year's imprisonment, and the others to various terms of imprisonment ranging from six mouths to three years. They sang the "Internationale" when they were removed.
(Router)
It has been finally decided that the Morocco Conference will meet at Algeciras.
(Reuter)
Speaking at Dunfermline, Sir Henry Gamy bell-Bannerman said that Liberals look upon Free Trade as being the settled policy of the country.
He was not in favour of a separate independent parliament for Ireland. Any legislative body for Ireland that might ever be voted mast be subordinate to the Imperial Parliament.
(Reuter)

Speaking at Belford, Sir E. Grey said that the stopping of the introduction of Chinese labour into the Transvaal must be followed by the introduction of responsible government, to put the Transvaal on an equal footing with other colonies.
He did not hesitate to say that votes given for Free Trade would not be used in support of Home Rule.
(Reuter)

Speaking at Queen's Hall. Mr. Balfour referred especially to the question of Home Rale. Wbat the oonntry wanted to know was whether the Government intended to give Ireland separate executive, responsible to a separate eleotive body. If so this was the very form of Mr. Gladstone's Home Rule bill.
(Reuter)

The Duke of Devonshire, in a manifesto, declares that it is improbable that the Government would risk the introduction of a Home Rule bill during the next parliament. The fiscal issue cannot be shelved, and it is therefore the duty of Free Trade Unionists, where they are unable to secure direct representation, to act so as to show that all Unionists are not committed to support Protection. (Reuter)
New Labour candidates are appearing at the last moment, increasing the number of triangular duals, which the Liberals estimate may endanger thirty seats. (Renter)

The revenue for the three months ending 31st December shows an increase of £23,598, and for the nine months of the financial year an increase of £97,948, as compared with the same periods of last year. (Reuter)
The Chamber of Commerce in this city and at Hamburg, after most cordial speeches, resolved to support the movement in favour of better Anglo-German relations. (Reuter)
H.M.S. Sapphire, which is still at Kiel, has been recalled to England. (Reuter)
Lieutenant General von Moltke, nephew of Count von Moltke, the Franco-German Commander, has been appointed Chief of the General Staff, in place of General Schlieffen, who has retired. (R.)

At the New Year reception at the Elysee, Count Tornielli, the Italian Ambassador, speaking on behalf of the diplomatic corps, expressed their satisfaction with the Russo-Japanese peace, and the advance of the international peace movement. President Loubet concurred, and deduced the most favourable conclusions from the pacific dispositions of the world. (R.)
Of forty two aliens from Hamburg arrived at Grimsby, twenty-four have been rejected under the new act, which is being enforced from to-day.
The immigrants were disqualified on account of lack of means, but they have appealed on account of being Russian refugees. (R.)
The New Zealand football team has concluded its tour in Great Britain. It has only been defeated once, and has scored 830 to 39. Yesterday it beat Swansea by 4 to 3, (Reuter)
Football. The New Zealanders defeated France by 30 to 8. (R.)
Considerable explosive material has been discovered at Demir Hissar. Numerous arrests have been made. (Havas)

div.head: Circulaire H. do Vries et Boutlgny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Caire, 30 décembre
Les valeurs égyptiennes sont encore rensegnées eu hausse à Londres ; la National Bank et l'Agricole ont gagné hier 1/8 de livre à 26 3/8 et 9 1/4.
A Paris l'action Crédit Foncier a fléchi de 2 francs à 776. La Banque d'Athènes a avancé d'un franc à 127.
Ici, le marché des valeurs a été ce matin remarquablement actif avec tendance ferme.
L'Agricole a gagné 1/16 à 9 3/8. La National Bank s'est maintenue à 25 7/16 ; l'action nouvelle s'est inscrite à 24 3/4.
Fort mouvement sur la Banque d'Abyssinie, qui a avancé jusqu'à 7 3/16 pour clôtnrer à 7.
La Cassa di Sconto est soutenue à 214; l'action nouvelle est en hausse d'un franc à 211.
La Banque d'Athènes a clôturé à 131.
Ire Crédit Foncier progresse à 782, en bonne demande ; les obligations à lots 1886 ont santé de 326 à 333.
L'Immobilière, sur laquelle noue avons attiré hier l'attention de nos lecteurs, monte à 352, en hausse de 14 francs ; la part de fondateur avance de 10 francs à 480.
Les Improvements Corporation sont recherchés à 4 9/16.
L'action Bourse Khédiviale du Carré fiait un nouveau bond de £140 à 152.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont été traités à 11 5/8 pour clôturer à 11 9/16. Les Upper Egypt avancent à 5 3/16 et les Splendid Hotels à 4 9/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian montent à 30 sh. et les Estates s'échangent par gros paquets à 1 9/16.

Dans le discours qu'il a prononcé à l'Assem blée Générale Ordinaire de la Delta Land, tenue à Londres le 21 décembre courant, le président, Sir Auckland Colvin, a annoncé que la Société se propose de lotir les terrain qu'elle a achetés dans les villes d'Egypte poor les vendre comme terrains de construction on bien pour bâtir pour son propre compte. La Société aiderait financièrement, an besoin les acheteurs de ces terrains.

Sir Auckland Colvin est persuadé qu'an Caire et dans d'antres centres importants il y aurait tout avantage pour la Compagnie à construire sur ces terrains des villas, des maisons de rapport, des bureaux et des magasins. Elle en tirerait de fort beaux loyers.

Il importe de noter que sur les 479 feddans de terrains achetés par la Compagnie, 49 sont situés avantageusement au centre du Caire, Tantah et antres grandes villes. Eu outre, la Société est intéressée pont un sixième dan des achats de terrains urbains faits par d'autres Compagnies.
Les cours du coton sont arrivés en baisse d'Amérique ; le Janvier a perdu hier 13 points et le Mai 12. Le marché de Liverpool est également pins faible.
Les arrivages ont été de 36,000 balles contre 32,000.
Ici, le Mars a ouvert ce matin à 15 9/16 pour clôturer an môme prix.
La Bourse Khédiviale du Caire étant fermée lundi prochain à l'occasion du Nouvel An notre Circulaire ne paraîtra pas ce jour-là.

MM. H. de Vries et Bontigny, agents de change, se chargent de l'exécution de 'ous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An vers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de ta maison est envoyée sur lemande.

Les travaux de réparation sont poussés très activement ; aussitôt qu'ils seront achevés le Public sera prévenu de la date à partir de laquelle ce pont pourra être réouvert.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS
LISTE ELECTORALE GENERALE MUNICIPALE POUR L'ANNEE 1906.

Le Public est informé que la liste électorale générale municipale pour l'année 1906 est affichée du 1er au 15 janvier 1906 an Gouvernorat, à la Bourse Khédiviale, à la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal et à la Municipalité, où toute personne pourra la consulter.

Les personnes qui enraient des réclamations faire pourront les présenter jusqu'au 31 janvier 1906 à M. le Vice Président de la Commission Municipale, lequel en référera à cette Assemblée qui statuera en dernier ressort.

En cas de réclamation, les personnes intéressées devront produire les justifications nécessaires (quittances de la taxe du 2 % etc.) afin d'en permettre le contrôle sur les registres du service des Recettes.
Des formules imprimées sont à la disposition des réclamants à la Municipalité.
Le Gouvernent
de la Ville d'Alexandrie,
Alexandria la 30 décembre 1905. 27024-3-1

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
div.p: AVIS
Il est porté à la connaissance du public que le Conseil d'Administration de la Société a décidé du réduire de 22 % le prix de l'eau fournie aux Bornes-fontaines publiques.
Eu conséquence, à partir du 1er Janvier 1906 on pourra obtenir l'eau aux dites fou taints à raison de P T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le uètre cube au lieu de P.T. 3,857 payées jusqu'ici.

Cette réduction de prix ayant été décidée par a Société dans le seul but d'en faire profiter les habitants de la Ville, le public est prié de veiller à ce que la dite réduction lui soit faite pat les sakas qui lui fournissent l'eau, afin de ne pas laisser ces derniers proficer du rabais qui n'a été consenti qu'en faveur du public.
La vente d'eau au détail aux Bornes-fontainés, s'établit donc comme soit :
Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 millièmes
La gaerbe de 66 „ „ .2 „
L'estagnon de 22 „ „ 3/4 „
et pour tonte quantité dépassant la jauge cidessus, chaque 4 kilos seront comptés à 1/8 de millièmes.
Le Caire, le 19 Décembre 1905.
La Directeur
ASTLEY P. FRIEND.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN SWINDLE.
div.p: SAMPLE CONSIGNMENT TRICK.
We extract the following from an American commercial newspaper :—

Last week we mentioned the unfortunate experience of one manufacturer in sending a prospective foreign customer a sample consignment of machinery. Another instance of the Bane kind has just come to notice. This is a case where an Egyptian firm, showing what purported to be genuine recommendations from the British Consul at Cairo and others, induced an American manufacturer to ship him on consignment one machine for sample purposes. The shipment was sent forward in the usual way, no conditions being imposed upon the Egyptian before he obtained delivery of the goods, except the implied obligation to display the machine in operation and use it as a means to developing the trade.

After the machine reached its destination the manufacturer was unable by any system of correspondence yet known to obtain an acknowledgment of its arrival until he threatened to bring the matter to the attention of the Cairo banks and the British Consul in that city. This threat brought forth the long deferred acknowledgment, supplemented by the explanation that the Egyptian had had no time to install the machine and that he did not understand how it was to be used anyway. The wily Oriental promised to deliver it over to anyone appointed by the manufacturer. The latter quickly made arrangements for the delivery of the machine to an American firm with Egyptian connections and this house at once set out to capture the goods.

Upon presenting its order for the goods it was told that the goods would be delivered upon the payment of some $60 or more to cover various vague and uncertain expenses, such as warehouse charges, customs dues, etc. The manufacturer now has the option of contributing this amount to the Egyptian's bank account or suffering a total loss on the transaction. This incident serves only as one more illustration to honest importers of the reason why American manufacturers look with suspicion upon all sample consignment invitations received from whatever source.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: AUTHORIZED CRUELTY.
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir—On Saturday morning, the 30th December, in the Nebi Daniel-street at 9 a.m., I saw a waggon, like the "Arabieh el Soda," stop. There were four employees of the Alexandria Municipality pitting upon it. Two of them descended, and one need a kind of whip as a lasso, with which he laid hold of a large dog by the neck. Another employee then caught the dog round the neck with a pair of iron pliers, looking like medical forceps, with a fourfold handle, which on closing gave a most unmerciful squeeze on the large neck of the dog. Another employee tied the dog's hind legs. The man with the pliers then tried to lift the dog on to the top of the box of the cart, where the lid was, a height of about six feet, and in doing so the man let go of the dog, who fell with a heavy thud on to the paving stones. The same thing happened a second time, each attempt bringing forth cheers of derision from the assembled crowd. At the third attempt, they succeeded in getting the dog into their cart.

I wish to call your attention to the brutal, clumsy, and cruel way in which this affair was conducted, and to ask if the S.P.C.A. could not take this matter in band, and forbid the Municipality acting in this un-business-like, clumsy, cruel, and brutal manner.
If the S.P.C A. is still in existence, I cannot understand how they have not already taken this matter in-hand, instead of leaving it to the initiative of the public.
A LOVER OF DUMB ANIMALS.
Alexandria, 30th December, 1905.

div.head: EGYPTIAN BISHOPRIC FUND.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF 1H5 EGYPTIAN GAZEITE.

Sir,—As an old resident and supporter of the Anglican Church at Alexandria, I cannot allow the excellent leader in your Saturday's issue to pass without expressing my entire concurrence in the views it contains. I confess to being much amazed to learn by the English "dailies" that two worthy and aged Bishops should contemplate such a step as starting a fond for a second Bishopric in the Khedive's dominions, and before they bad raised sufficient funds to enable them to carry out their first project, i.e., the Egyptian Bishopric. The suggestion in your leader of raiding an income on the money already collected for the latter object, so as to enable our new Archdeacon, Bishop Morley, to travel about Egypt and fulfil his archidiaconal duties, is an admirable one. At present, without a travelling allowance, Bishop Morley's functions most, I imagine, be confined to those of chaplain at Assouan, although he should be in a position to relieve Dr. Blyth of most of his episcopal duties in Egypt. With the additional income of £250 a year, to be derived from the interest on the existing Egyptian Bishopric Fund, he would be enabled to move about as Suffragan Bishop when required. Should the Sudan authorities require his services they might, by giving him a free pass on their railways and steamers, with the hospitality always shown in the United Kingdom to Bishops when on their episcopal tours, procure his assent to visiting them on stated occasions.

Assouan would be a central position for a Bishop acting for the united diocese of Egypt and the Sudan during the winter months. At any rate this arrangement would fill up the gap until the Bishopric was placed on a more permanent footing. One Bishop capable of the necessary physical exertion should be equal to carrying out the episcopal duties both of Egypt and the Sudan. Union is strength, and if the two funds were amalgamated and the diocese called Egypt and the Sudan, the money would be raised more quickly than if two impoverished and rival Sees were created in the same country.—Yours faithfully,
ANGLICANUS.
New Year's Eve, 1905.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: For the company of Royal Garrison Artillery, stationed in Egypt, eighteen paid layers and two paid range takers are to be allowed.

Lieutenant J.G.E. Craik, 2nd Battalion Seaforth Highlanders, has been formally seconded for service with the Egyptian Army. Lieutenant Craik has worn the tartan for nearly six years, and saw considerable service with the 2nd Bettalion of the Seaforths in the South African War, including the operations in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony (medal with three clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

The Army Council has decided to stop all leave of officers desirous of going to Russia in consequence of the disturbed state of affairs in that unhappy country. Leave will be permitted when public tranquillity has been restored, which may be a long time in coming.
The competition for the Centenary Cup of the Royal Garrison Artillery is to be discontinued. So it has been officially notified.

The return, just issued, of the result of the gun-layers' competition in his Majesty's Fleet in 1905, shows an improvement generally in shooting. The Lords of the Admiralty note with much satisfaction the great improvement in the results as compared with former years. The conditions under which the practice took place were different to those of the previous year, the range in 1903 having been reverted to. This range is shorter by 1000 yards, but the target is also smaller for guns above 9.2 inch. The return shows that the Mediterranean battle squadron took fifth place, the flagship Bulwark heading the list with a score of 114.04 points. The other ships in the order of merit were—Venerable, Venus, Formidable, Goliath, Queen, Diana, Prince of Wales, Minerva, Irresistible, Implacable, and London. The Third Cruiser Squadron, attached to the Mediterranean Fleet, took second place in the following order of merit—Leviathan (flagship), Suffolk, Carnarvon, and Lancaster.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA
div.p: LA DOGARESSE

Ecrire un opkra — surtout lorsqu'ils'agit de 3 actes — n'est certainement pas une mince affaire. Les ta'ents musicaux les mieox douka ont souvent kehouk dans une telle entreprise, qn'il n'est doonk qu'k un petit nombre de musiciens touchant au gknie de mener à bien.

La vieille kc >le exigeait qne dans l'opkra la mklodie fut jetke k pleines mains, tandis qu'aveo les progrks de la symphonie on pent faoilement mknager oelle-ci. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
